        "body": "Believe me, it's not all about the writing.\n\nOf course, the story/information needs to be good, edited, correctly laid out and formatted etc. The book itself needs more than all that, however.\n\n\n![3ACB4805-4504-4F0E-BC81-1CC61104A910_1_105_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmSaeUYEsnXg7CzzLvXpBQ3rP7D2zNWVL3eo4FubtDJq7J/3ACB4805-4504-4F0E-BC81-1CC61104A910_1_105_c.jpeg)\n\n\nLast night, we were invited to a book launch and just like a rocket launch, preparations months in advance all culminated in the success of last night.\n\nIn December last year, I was contacted by a lovely lady who desperately needed help with her first fiction novel. She was recommended to me by a long-standing friend and I connected with her immediately. She's really up-beat, knowledgeable and intelligent and she knows her stuff on the subject of marketing - four-times-best-seller on the subject.\n\nI promised I could help and I set to work. I sent over a couple of paragraphs of editing to show her how I work, and she and her husband agreed I was up to the task.\n\nThen disaster struck!\n\nI sent off the first part and she phoned me to tell me she didn't like what I'd done. She was upset (rightly so) and said she'd pay the money we'd agreed, but it wasn't what she wanted.\n\nI told her that's not how I work and I'd take it all back to the beginning and start again. \n\nFrom there, it went like a dream. I edited each short story with the minimum of fuss and stress and she began to feel confident in our working relationship.\nThe book was already to a higher standard than a lot of the novels I've read/started to read. It helps if you have a good idea of how to construct and deliver a story and of course, a grasp of English (or the language in which you're publishing) is a huge bonus.\n\nThe problem we had at the beginning of the relationship was that I misunderstood the brief and got a little heavy-handed. The Author wanted the lightest of touches, a mere polish to make her diamond shine. I started over and delivered exactly what she wanted and that effort has paid out on both sides.\n\n![image.png](https://images.hive.blog/DQmaeF76MLGdnF79i6VAss7pihyJQLdtH4k5qoLu3a4Ajdk/image.png)\n\n\nI now know what a great client looks like. She was wonderful to work with, she knew exactly what she wanted and was able to communicate everything to me without fuss, stress or crisis. For my part, she received a great editing service that elevated her novel beyond the excellence she had already achieved.\n\nWe have become good friends and she invited me to her exclusive book launch.\n\nLike a graceful swan, she's been gliding along the surface of a tranquil lake, making everything look so easy. Under the waterline, however, her efforts have been enormous! From planning the exact wording for her book on Amazon, to emailing contacts left, right and centre - making new contacts, reaffirming old contacts and working it!\n\nShe has divulged many secrets to her success and I'm determined to make the most of that valuable asset - knowledge.\n\nI helped Dee get her book finished and polished and in turn (though she doesn't know it), she's boosted my confidence and got me writing again. I'm determined to publish anther book by the end of this year and there's more to come too.\n\nHere's the start - two days in a row of writing on Hive.Blog. I think I may be on my way back 'home' - to where I love writing again.\n\nWatch this space, there's a [Dee Blick Rocket](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Boutique-GRIPPING-POWERFUL-POIGNANT-STORIES-ebook/dp/B0DWG6Q5RG) about to take off - Public Launch is tomorrow!",

        "body": "Landed yesterday - well, we're debating whether we landed or were shot down, to be honest. Either the runway has potholes or the suspension on the plane needs sorting out.\n\n![B6AEB066-0534-41FC-B624-11D0862EFE43_1_102_o.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmWBC6AQhs33xEj5i5CGmaTCokvPK38Qn2oP9Y1GHc4yu7/B6AEB066-0534-41FC-B624-11D0862EFE43_1_102_o.jpeg)\n*My own pictures*\n\nCollected the hire car and made our way to Horsham and the hotel. I was tired and sore by the time we got to our room.\n\nThis morning, I met with Dee Blick - best-selling author of three non-fiction books. Today is the launch of her first fiction novel and @s0u1 and I are invited to the launch! So exciting!\n\n[The Boutique](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Boutique-GRIPPING-POWERFUL-POIGNANT-STORIES-ebook/dp/B0DWG6Q5RG)\n![3ACB4805-4504-4F0E-BC81-1CC61104A910.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmQU5UidFu56xfXiNqx2Q8MjEwEYx8wgHarMad4VWqpzrY/3ACB4805-4504-4F0E-BC81-1CC61104A910.jpeg)\n*My own pictures*\n\n\nDee is another 'Northern Lass' and we had a lovely chat. I think I monopolised her time a bit too much though and I know she's so busy today! Sorry, Dee.\n\nIt's been a while since we were last in the UK and not at 'home' in Derbyshire/Nottinghamshire. We're on a 'proper' holiday. I'm missing my animals back home, though.\n\n![8B31416A-FA61-43DA-A344-FD89BE05F2F7.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmfKpisf5Q5kegpeGDawWTpFph8ZfUsSooW7GbVNBkjbww/8B31416A-FA61-43DA-A344-FD89BE05F2F7.jpeg)\n*My own pictures*\n![3264426B-DE5D-4AFE-A5C8-1EA798CE8110_4_5005_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmR29tDFzTXF5wHF2QagELpcoVU22TPvLrfVS8ycVeowvs/3264426B-DE5D-4AFE-A5C8-1EA798CE8110_4_5005_c.jpeg)\n*My own pictures*\n\nThe plan this week is to do some stuff we don't usually do - eat out, drink in pubs, take leisurely walks to nowhere in particular, you know the usual 'vacation stuff'.\n\n\n![6920E929-AEDC-4FC1-873E-D36DA9FC6C6F_1_106_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmNzQRPy6VzVNroWgywMbeXkTU9TgDvDkig18okc9jM15G/6920E929-AEDC-4FC1-873E-D36DA9FC6C6F_1_106_c.jpeg)\n\nNot that we don't love our new life in France, of course. The walks are normally across hills, fields and woodlands, the meals are mostly home-cooked (and home-grown food), delicious, filling and satisfying, but then someone has to do the washing up after... Drinking in pubs is a different activity to drinking in bars or at home - don't ask me why, it just is.\n\n\n![26730C9B-40F5-4DB5-88F3-FE9C3B7FC992.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmPNpZYQtu8AiF5HWMzCvBmd1HWchz5GFY3by15ATCEFyD/26730C9B-40F5-4DB5-88F3-FE9C3B7FC992.jpeg)\n*My own pictures*\n\nAs usual, I'm not really sure where this post is going, I just sat down to write, and this is what I got - so this is what you got...\n\nMore tomorrow, I hope. After the Book launch!",

        "beneficiaries": [],
        "body": "Hey! Just a note to say I'm not dead!\nOh boy, we've been having some adventures lately. I've not been writing, but I have picked up my pen and notepad (laptop) and started revisiting some older projects.\n\n![41DD37F6-9BED-428F-A755-158F16F1E938_1_105_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmS2uRNMx2DNriC6SNopyAhy782D7tytxih3tvRDh9Y1Zo/41DD37F6-9BED-428F-A755-158F16F1E938_1_105_c.jpeg)\n\n\nToday is a blustery kind of day and I had a late start of it. I lay in bed too long, doomscrolling, and was kinda late getting to the horses (not that they minded, they weren't over-enthusiastic to get out of their shelters and into the wind-swept fields). The horses had hay left and were impatient for their breakfast.\n\n![34502713-3797-4304-B35A-41673BBC2984.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmW3ZEC4MGhqJubUS3HMD5WxixdWCN7R1YucD23JqdwrCX/34502713-3797-4304-B35A-41673BBC2984.jpeg)\n\n\nAfter taking them across the road, into their field, I fed the wild birds - not quite such an easy task as it sounds, I had to mix the feed first and then battle the elements to refill the feeders.\n\nThen I came indoors and started organising the story I wrote 7 years ago on the 'other place'.  I think it still 'has legs' and I can do something with it.\n\n\n![7B630187-BD26-41E1-ACBB-1279C048DA66.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVxfXBcEGg5e5KSQnX1h4XrmektG7cdq2oTUriqadxaib/7B630187-BD26-41E1-ACBB-1279C048DA66.jpeg)\n\n\n\nWatching the wind whip around the trees outside, I got distracted and that led me to Hive.Blog, so here I am (again), making another sporadic post about still being an inhabitant of this marvellous planet.\n\nWe'll be travelling to England in the next week, I've been invited to a book launch and I'm really excited to meet the Author of [The Boutique](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Boutique-GRIPPING-POWERFUL-POIGNANT-STORIES-ebook/dp/B0DWG6Q5RG/), Dee Blick. \n\n![image.png](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUcBBzc1vgVm6tpcEjeUXcG7FPNRhP7zCZTQnoAQgFAgg/image.png)\n\n\nAfter the book launch, we're travelling up-country to celebrate @s0u1's mum's 100th birthday.\n\nCatching up with friends and family, we'll then head home to start getting the house ready for visitors over Easter and the summer season.\n\nIt looks like being another fabulous year here and if I'm really lucky, I'll give my head a good wobble and get back to writing - not just stories, but more blogs about our new life here.\n\n\n![D4AE534D-0410-4059-AA03-A609E4E98A5E.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmU7Mp85NtukV6r5beHatLaa9nSngg2XfdqPfGesGseXGE/D4AE534D-0410-4059-AA03-A609E4E98A5E.jpeg)\n\n\nI have so much to tell you...\n\nUntil the next time!",

        "body": "We had rain last night. Not a deluge, not even what you’d call ‘a lot’ of rain, but we had enough to make me happy.\n\n![IMG_2958.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbJp3W3Tt6UovmPaC6EZiNY9VxSQtuoncnjBSqNxS3rK6/IMG_2958.JPG)\n*Horses with the windrows in the background*\n![IMG_2959.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTeGAUTxyfvuwQAw7xchsxq5MssSLAcw2qoWKdioQAqF5/IMG_2959.JPG)\n\n![IMG_2960.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbcKCfC6xVJCKm6CQxN1VcHYZA3z9rYLJyLBYuFURiWEb/IMG_2960.JPG)\n\nThis time, it’s not because we’re short of water and the crops need us to go out and water everything by hand – we do, but it’s not that.\n\nI’m delighted because of the work we put in yesterday.\n\nI’ll explain. Last week, I looked at the local weather forecast for the long-term weather over the next 10 days. It hinted at sun and clear skies from Saturday to next Saturday, when the weather would break, we’d get thunderstorms etc. So we had a good 7 or 8 days to get the fields cut, dried and gathered in – plenty of time!\n\n![IMG_2961.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmcRsNo7DCAjiPp4wNNgV3evdVFtganNNPjXmN3SekL2Yy/IMG_2961.JPG)\n*This is the length of the grass - it has got a bit too long...*\n\nWe couldn’t cut the grass on Saturday and Sunday because the ground was so waterlogged the tractor would create furrows and damage the fields, so we planned to mow on Monday, tedder on Wednesday, tedder again on Thursday and collect on Friday and Saturday.\n\nThat would have been ideal… On Monday, Farmer @s0u1 went to mow, went to mow a meadow. One man and his dog, Tora, went to mow a meadow. \n[Previous post](https://hive.blog/hive-124999/@michelle.gent/working-outdoors-in-the-sunshine)\n\nThen the forecast started to change. For next Saturday, instead of the thunderstorms coming at the end of the day, late on, they were forecast to arrive early. Our plans changed accordingly. \nMonday – mow\nTuesday – tedder\nWednesday – tedder again\nThursday – collect the Vineyard Paddock\nFriday – collect the Lake View Paddock\n\nAnd so, we mowed.\n\nOn Tuesday the weather was starting to concern us. It forecast one slight chance of rain on Thursday morning. 30% chance, for 1 hour. That shouldn’t have been too much of a worry, unless you added in the changes in the rest of the forecast. Thunderstorms were moving toward us at quite a rapid pace. They were forecast on Friday, all day, rather than just sporadic on Saturday. Now we had thunder on Friday, Saturday and possibly Sunday, but also, three days of rain.\n\nFarmer @s0u1 went to tedder both fields on Tuesday and we hoped the sun would come out with enough intensity to dry the hay completely in just those two days.\n\nTuesday afternoon we decided to tedder the fields again, just to give us some leeway.\n\nI’m glad we did!\n\nThursday’s forecast turned from 30% chance of rain for an hour to full-day showers. If hay gets wet before collecting, it can go mouldy in storage. You absolutely cannot feed mouldy hay to horses.\n\nWe planned our day accordingly, but even then, the plans went a little awry.\n\nWednesday morning, the plan was to get started as soon as possible. The Vineyard Paddock gets full sun first, so that’s where I started. @s0u1 had planned one last turn of the hay and he was going to do that while I began collecting the other field.\nI went out on the quad bike to begin, but the night had been foggy, and the grass and hay were still damp. I had to leave it at least a couple of hours to dry completely. @s0u1 went out into the Lake View field and came back with the same conclusion – too wet.\n\nMid-day, I went out to start collecting the hay. Thankfully, the sun had done its work and I began pushing the windrows into clumps to make it easier to collect. \n\n\n![IMG_2962.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTZqU768YxDxywAHXVp9vsBNd8tQuK75PcNE1hMBVVSJn/IMG_2962.JPG)\n*I have a technique. I walk a few yards up the windrow, decide where to start from, then I place the pitchfork into the starting point and push. I keep the tines of the fork turned up so they don't dig into the ground and I push all the hay into one large pile. Then I move to the next and so on.*\n\nI started at the closest end, worked to half way and went up to the top to work back to the middle. Let me tell you, working in the mid-day sun is hard. We had a little respite with a breeze, but not enough and I was stubborn and stupid as it turned out. I was determined to finish what I’d started and by the end of that part of the work, I was struggling. I could hardly lift my feet to walk back. I made it to the gate where I had a rest and then went indoors. Trev brought me a glass of water – not straight from the fridge, that’s not the way to go when someone needs a drink immediately. My throat spasmed and felt like it was closing up. I took a small drink of water and the spasm eased a little.\n\nI have never experienced that before. It was scary! I could breathe, but not swallow or talk. I stretched and moved my neck to try to ease the spasm and nothing worked. I was on the verge of panic.\nWhen I was going through chemo and radiotherapy, I was told by the nurse that I must NOT eat or drink anything straight from the fridge because the chemo I was taking caused my body to be hyper-sensitive to cold and I could go into anaphylactic shock. What a time to have a flash-back memory! I don’t think it was a residue of the chemo treatment that caused the spasm (it’s been a long time, plus I was too hot, not too cold) but my brain went there, anyway!\nI sat and recovered for a while. When I finally went back outside, my legs were still wobbly, @s0u1 told me to go back indoors, but I couldn’t leave him to do all the work on his own.\n\nMid-afternoon, we took a break and went indoors to watch the launch of the space shuttle thing - Starliner.\n\nThen we went back out to work.\n\n![IMG_2964.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmP9Fhj4U8sBMjDz6yMeHRfuyzU6zNWbZkb5ovm81yLmiV/IMG_2964.JPG)\n*Bagged and waiting*\n\n![IMG_2965.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTXyZHBUoPm5Y5NePnfNDiJcoCuxfsTUqhLEohz1Qvq4K/IMG_2965.JPG)\n*Getting desperate for bags, we utilised garden bags*\n\n![IMG_2966.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYZ41wd1HJThbsUAn8spBnDQM3KUpiRCfK2kpvuLHihc7/IMG_2966.JPG)\n\n![IMG_2967.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVitcfo88YkfNDCVi2T6P2TmLH1kpqVTpRRgkVTJkX8Nm/IMG_2967.JPG)\n\nIt was getting late by the time we started putting the hay in the barn, but we still had a long way to go before we’d finished. We knew we didn’t have enough bags to store the hay, so we had to adapt.\n\n![IMG_2969.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVjumX7H7cRohgL57pisGoqNd6iTZTGoUPeD7phsiD1w2/IMG_2969.JPG)\n\n*The box in front is last year's hay. This year's hay is green and still bright. There's nothing wrong with last year's hay. The horses will get through that during the hot season this year, when the grass doesn't grow and we have to supplement their feed*\n\n![IMG_2970.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXfiTme9LZjh3rCB12An9XBxXHUopsN13MrA1MkvMcSit/IMG_2970.JPG)\n*The first two loads brought in and stacked*\n\nWe’d planned to stack the bags full of hay in the barn, but we still needed almost as many bags as we’d filled, just to get the Lake View Paddock in.\nThe new plan was to stack the hay in the barn using the ‘sandcastle method’. Re-utilising the bags in this way saved a lot of time. Once we’d brought in all the hay from the Vineyard Paddock, we had a drink and set-to to fetch the last of the hay in.\n\n![IMG_2971.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVEGjXCXAQA7jg2Z6h2ZzxoCGcWkxgoUMtf58ekXN8Gm7/IMG_2971.JPG)\n*Obviously the hay doesn't stack as well out of the bag...*\n\n![IMG_2972.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmX5hXRnptnY8gvKE7wf7DuSMFbNAmpYj24fLTLbFtThjm/IMG_2972.JPG)\n*Almost done with this field, we're just on our last load from Vineyard Paddock*\n\n\n![IMG_2975.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmQApQjnCFrZVy55P5SnjCTQsijmuqWun3SErrrQ3o521o/IMG_2975.JPG)\n*We still have to bale this if we can*\n\nThe horses were fascinated. The dog was being silly and even though we were getting close to sunset, it was still hot. I took Tora indoors for her own good.\n![IMG_2978.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUwQvi97ZfBq9qawf7XwHGPZ9t85QhhspAvZwgJYY76kw/IMG_2978.JPG)\n*Corner of Lake View Paddock with one windrow in shade, the other in full sun, just before sunset*\n\n![IMG_2979.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmejAcpSoYwcmwkaZjQzwwYAyFF4st9qHXfVTKxc296tNk/IMG_2979.JPG)\n*All bagged up. You can see the difference - the sky is clear, no clouds, but the sun has set behind the trees, just about to get dark*\n\n\n@s0u1 went to put the chickens away and check/close-up the greenhouse. Unfortunately, the plants didn’t get watered last night, they’d have to wait.\n\nAt last, we’d packed the hay into bags and then we team-worked to getting the bags back to the house. One bag was bungeed to the rack on the back of the quad bike and @s0u1 drove close to another bag, which I grabbed and dragged behind us. I had to brace myself with the opposing hand on the back rack, and he had to be careful driving through the orchard so we didn’t wipe-out any of the new trees, but we made it.\n\nWe fetched the last bags in at around 21:30. The sun had set, but it was still light enough to see what we were doing, especially with the benefit of the quad bike’s lights.\n\n![IMG_2980.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmeSDTSkr1buYctVWmp98Y5ppMH3ahnhGmmCH1zh7gFo8t/IMG_2980.JPG)\n*All in from the field, just a fence to dismantle in order to get the bags into the stable where they will be stored for the moment*\n\nThe total of 20 bags from the Vineyard Paddock and 12 and a half from Lake View Paddock was packed and stored, with just the tractor and ride-on mower to put away. It was almost full-dark when I fetched him from the barn and I hope the neighbours will forgive the noise we made in putting everything away at 22:30 or thereabouts.\n\n![IMG_2981.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmPdNbLrKgEP18HmEnGYF2UCFxn6KwZpjWSCNoBrmqwCfu/IMG_2981.JPG)\n*Last picture before putting the vehicles away*\n\nWe had soup for supper (packet mix, kettle, boiled water) and then we collapsed into bed, seized-up and mindful of our advancing years!\n\nThis morning, it had rained and all our efforts were vindicated. We could have taken a chance, but I am so glad we didn’t. Make hay while the sun shines!\n\n29 degrees for a good part of the day yesterday. I remember at one point, he said, \"It's going to get 2 degrees hotter before it starts cooling down.\" I was baked by then (and not in a good way).\nI ache in places I'd forgotten about and my arm and chest muscles can tell their own tale about dragging bags of hay behind a quad bike!\n\n![IMG_2982.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmWyde8mX561wzatjf25umUoVo7maAbpWBub3LPMk3PddR/IMG_2982.JPG)\n*This morning - Vineyard Paddock*\n\n![IMG_2983.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmY75dkk1CsNc6GspZF6WTjdiJYzTKUC8o8iYTEiQRhH7Z/IMG_2983.JPG)\n*This morning Lake View Paddock*\n\n![IMG_2984.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmejNeRnBte2ZbdqYswBPdVmvzLzbXRGt2hDUdSAynrAUv/IMG_2984.JPG)\n*Where we put the hay last night to save time*",

        "body": "What a glorious day we had yesterday!\n\n\n![D9D628A1-EFD6-486F-8D85-291E3959680E_1_105_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmRMCThuLzxQAeQrxgQEgcjfULMjKYFEaHh2NsGU74fCyX/D9D628A1-EFD6-486F-8D85-291E3959680E_1_105_c.jpeg)\n\n\nActually, the days have started to be warmer lately, but we still have cool nights, so the pool is STILL not open.  \nA little way north of us in Le Mans, the famous 24 hour race was stopped because of the heavy fog and I'm sure that's part of the unusual weather we're having this year.\n*Edit: It was the Nurburgring 24 hr race that was stopped due to fog, not Le Mans -N24 stopped after 8 hours*\n\nAnyway, back to our work.\nWe have four fields to mow for hay this year. It's getting late, but we've not been able to cut the grass so far because it wouldn't have had chance to dry. I spotted that we had a few days of sunshine coming and we made our plans.\n\n![E3D57543-E1D7-4102-B2EC-2BBEE0661257_1_105_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVyx3vBko6aNjvheb4EQsWkZa5ysVPRy9Urtcn2DQwanQ/E3D57543-E1D7-4102-B2EC-2BBEE0661257_1_105_c.jpeg)\n*One of the preparation walks for cutting hay*\n\n![79A4B92F-1476-4CF1-AF2E-6B157AD2425F_1_105_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmdfWE8QyHwvB6FCaBrU1bC4wGUL5vkSbsxhqyWLamLQN2/79A4B92F-1476-4CF1-AF2E-6B157AD2425F_1_105_c.jpeg)\n*Tora found something*\n\n![BE59722B-58A7-4328-A4CE-62FED43E7447_1_105_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmRLdBfQBT27nAy1AEkXhWTKkm1o92Ex3z6FdWQsiqhTyt/BE59722B-58A7-4328-A4CE-62FED43E7447_1_105_c.jpeg)\n*The grass is a little longer than we'd like, we've been advised to cut it just before the seed heads flower, but it wasn't possible this year*\n\nThe Vineyard Paddock and the top strip of Lake View Paddock were planned in for hay-making. Yesterday we walked the Vineyard Paddock to check for ragwort - a toxic weed that can kill horses (and other animals). We pulled a few stray bits from the paddock, but I spotted clumps of it growing in the hedgerow and we had to scramble through broom, trees, undergrowth and blackthorn to get it all before it casts its seeds and becomes a worse problem.\n\n![E3861700-89B3-46C7-A4C9-F7BE9B3A1B90_1_106_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmQjh6wExJ6Cmdv5xeu1pjnWhgfKP8qBj862eXEASk8KXU/E3861700-89B3-46C7-A4C9-F7BE9B3A1B90_1_106_c.jpeg)\n*To the left is the Lake View Paddock. We fenced-off the top strip of that field*\n\n![99F1F481-B202-4D16-A831-55175AA452EE_1_105_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUhq4QbvooFgUnHwyzcDTifft1RCFDXeTHvvWYr8Uf5xX/99F1F481-B202-4D16-A831-55175AA452EE_1_105_c.jpeg)\n*You can see the white temporary fencing we've put up to stop the horses going into that part. They have enough grass in the lower part, so we decided to use the rest of the grass for extra hay*\n\n![96802155-3BBE-4A01-8233-EE66D387CC60_1_102_o.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmPSPZCF9MF93TUd3fACzrSNZQBjbYm1HHCZJS9zzNT9N2/96802155-3BBE-4A01-8233-EE66D387CC60_1_102_o.jpeg)\n*View from the top of Lake View Paddock*\n\nThe upside of that scrambling about, getting bitten/stung by something and scratched by the thorns is we have a NEW project to get into... **another one?**\nWe discovered a lot of 'wild vines' growing in the undergrowth and I think, if we can cut back the broom (I want to do that anyway) and the weeds, we can cultivate the vines and restore at least part of the original 1950s vineyard.\n\n![D8785D38-25C1-4399-BBC6-FF8DE673E50A.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUKYgqcujKjVLku9B4uQwtjFPiC7pzdQ9GWFS3vw65McJ/D8785D38-25C1-4399-BBC6-FF8DE673E50A.jpeg)\n*The tractor with the mower attached*\n\n![01F8F58C-46D8-4905-A137-86BB33D3F70E.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZXSs9NsjNZneDDbYFAegLUfWzofcSCu7PMxmm1ftM6sd/01F8F58C-46D8-4905-A137-86BB33D3F70E.jpeg)\n*The perspective of exactly how deep the grass has grown*\n\n![DA2C9A88-3A6E-4203-AD17-C6AF95B5EC30_1_102_o.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXqtbiTUF3T9oqKNnpgFVgjgeVZzhqWWDeF7BCn7soYDK/DA2C9A88-3A6E-4203-AD17-C6AF95B5EC30_1_102_o.jpeg)\n*The grass is a bit seedy, but beggars can't be choosers*\n\n![A4AADFB0-D0E0-46FC-9AC2-2F0D7C74F78D.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUQiGc9hPYRJA8GKWrEB2sAnAFGwTVv6AGXrmnPuKssUG/A4AADFB0-D0E0-46FC-9AC2-2F0D7C74F78D.jpeg)\n*The first cut - forward view*\n\n![9B2393F9-FBF5-4623-8510-0E7B012B98C3.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmdHbusoX9wMnCH4bcmMWYVQXWSj1aYYtrqFfirKktFRxy/9B2393F9-FBF5-4623-8510-0E7B012B98C3.jpeg)\n*The first cut - backward*\n\nLater that afternoon, Trev (@s0u1) mowed the southern end of the Vineyard Paddock and went to fetch the ride-on lawnmower. He then spot-mowed the ragwort 'florets' I found while walking in front of him, and collected that grass to put on the compost heap. We didn't want to risk any ragwort in the hay we're cutting. Ragwort tastes bitter to horses and while it grows, they instinctively leave it alone, but when it's cut and dried, it loses the bitterness and they eat it without realising. The poison is accumulative and never leaves their system, so it can kill them even years later.\n\n![5D945AD2-5030-4384-A02A-D195A4D3CB15.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYTnyEyBreTcaQseijFUoNvdvNQzpoPDEFzKQmVwp5qFh/5D945AD2-5030-4384-A02A-D195A4D3CB15.jpeg)\n\n![26F1D35A-B718-46B4-8F3F-607420BA599D_1_102_o.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZh4gHDxtS4BBq5ktWpRytCmW4TLq9JiKPeDKeVFF4e4B/26F1D35A-B718-46B4-8F3F-607420BA599D_1_102_o.jpeg)\n\n![A9017401-40FA-448B-9EDE-A4605355315D_1_102_o.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmQiezPJnqCqV5BHfQmYKGZJPvcBt7kFZNLHpmRuipDFkm/A9017401-40FA-448B-9EDE-A4605355315D_1_102_o.jpeg)\n\n![8DAD9FC8-8E24-401B-A220-D2DDB49D97A5_1_102_o.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmdTVaZuKPYL2aCmGfNmn5YeQqc1nTC6nnhkdgCAVUmNJB/8DAD9FC8-8E24-401B-A220-D2DDB49D97A5_1_102_o.jpeg)\n\n\nAs Trev was working, I set to and built two raised beds for the side of the stables. We need to put the horse-muck somewhere and raised beds are as good a place as any and once the beds are full, they can start the process of decomposition to turn into compost so we can grow stuff there. I'm planning on growing carrots for the horses, so it's a neat circle of nature.\n\n![DAB584E0-608E-4DC3-8851-4DE448F161E0_1_102_o.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZkDK52RxysEZpDgBy24qgzrMWwNKUpjsCu3C8DDBRwj8/DAB584E0-608E-4DC3-8851-4DE448F161E0_1_102_o.jpeg)\n*Just a couple of metre-square boxes to match the steps we're going to make.*\n\n![1651A34B-F52F-4B3A-8F33-F5EF4DAE77BF.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTK2KCvWsD2k5C5iKyEcctusvPCuHfLHNigh6iY5BrHXh/1651A34B-F52F-4B3A-8F33-F5EF4DAE77BF.jpeg)\n*The wood is part of the 'paquets' purchased from our local woodyard. We've spent approximately €1000 (rounded up) on lumber and so far we've estimated that work we've done using the purchased lumber would have cost in excess of €2000 plus if we had bought the wood from a store (and we have LOTS left)*\n\nTrev then mowed the rest of the Vineyard Paddock and moved on to the top strip of the Lake View Paddock. We've started to name the parcels of land so we can easily identify them. Our friends John and Liz told us about the names they've given to parcels of their property and we loved the idea and adopted it. We'll be making signs at some point and I'm looking forward to that!\n![IMG_8848.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmNobcSeD3fjXzwrFci29VVxn77vhTtTH8jiJ9Y6gBzQAQ/IMG_8848.jpeg)\n*Top corner of Lake View Paddock, looking towards Long Drop Woods*\n\n![IMG_8849.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmSANQopcU6sGyPqj8a7dtvVdLBiHdNFFxx9kei1vAAHym/IMG_8849.jpeg)\n*Same place, top corner, but looking back, towards the house. This is on the far northern border of our property on one side of the road*\n\n\n![IMG_8850.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbF9tPGnDUURWaib6nn8jcxmUXgSq54j3EdHv6GcCpLrm/IMG_8850.jpeg)\n*Top corner of Lake View Paddock, next to the fence for Long Drop Woods*\n\n![IMG_8854.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmfWm47zYfZrjHzGuBUVQVHu22jQhn7wJmzbdk4Zd5LHGx/IMG_8854.jpeg)\n*Same view, with the subtle difference that the first circuit of mowing has been made*\n\n![IMG_8854.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmP1CsJhqb6nmcYoq8upZkMqHH2J49b2Je5hMYTJKkezmh/IMG_8854.JPG)\n*Progress! The trees on the left are a little copse at the top of the field. Unfortunately, someone has dumped lots of metal and junk there over the years, so any cut grass that we can't really put on the compost heap, gets dumped there. Over the years, it will cover the junk and fill-in the ditch to make a nice (and fertile) area of shade*\n\n![IMG_8857.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmRx7CN9s2FPjsWAiSHc4gQGRnw8ksrS4PjWpnqUDik7G1/IMG_8857.jpeg)\n\n![IMG_8864.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmRRZAYdJwJ5CUz2ww7BSGDFa36aHxqaK5FGACa4EWNGVn/IMG_8864.jpeg)\n*Round and round he goes, where he stops, nobody knows!*\n\n\n\nI wasn't well yesterday and sat indoors for most of the afternoon.\n\nToday Trev is changing the Mower on the tractor for a Tedder. We bought it last year and it proved invaluable in collecting the hay. It makes it SO much easier.\n\nThe Tedder is a device that pulls all the wisps of dried grass together to make them into rows or 'Windrows' which you have probably seen in fields where you live. He'll turn the Windrows a couple of times to ensure the grass is really dry before we collect it up and store it in the barn.\n![IMG_8868.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVNmDRU5uzQhTTmD3S6E8dY74D7xCviRinRAwxjpxEppn/IMG_8868.jpeg)\n*One Tedder, fitted and ready to work*\n\n\n\n\nWe don't have a baler and so we collect the hay into builder's bags (white bags which can take 1 tonne of building material such as sand, gravel or hardcore). The first year we made hay, we got around 21 bags of hay. Last year we got 24 bags, plus a couple of tarpaulins full too (make-do and manage). I wonder what the tally will be this year.\n\n![IMG_7388 2.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmSrW5U3dLcJitYQ5j3aex8fQyDy3YAndPA2za1AgqPjuk/IMG_7388%202.jpeg)\n*The builder's bags we used last year*\n\n![IMG_7647 3.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmeqT61aPj96uXdBM6V39vdAhzAhjvX99zsC1k7qCugoDT/IMG_7647%203.jpeg)\n*Fashion in the Fields - lovely hat!*\n\nWe still have some of last year's hay left, which is terrific for us as it takes the pressure off, but we also have the Dordogne Field and the Long Field (work in progress with that name) to cut and fetch in, PLUS we may yet get another harvest (another cut) before the year is out.\n\nEnjoy the pictures, I'll update you on the Tedding tomorrow.\n\n![IMG_7391 2.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYq7cnKjo8nZR7ETTuEfGG8Nv4hkdGdBrP2K6aovBixpz/IMG_7391%202.jpeg)\n*Last year's haul!*",

01B-A220-D2DDB49D97A5_1_102_o.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmZkDK52RxysEZpDgBy24qgzrMWwNKUpjsCu3C8DDBRwj8/DAB584E0-608E-4DC3-8851-4DE448F161E0_1_102_o.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmTK2KCvWsD2k5C5iKyEcctusvPCuHfLHNigh6iY5BrHXh/1651A34B-F52F-4B3A-8F33-F5EF4DAE77BF.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmNobcSeD3fjXzwrFci29VVxn77vhTtTH8jiJ9Y6gBzQAQ/IMG_8848.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmSANQopcU6sGyPqj8a7dtvVdLBiHdNFFxx9kei1vAAHym/IMG_8849.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmbF9tPGnDUURWaib6nn8jcxmUXgSq54j3EdHv6GcCpLrm/IMG_8850.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmfWm47zYfZrjHzGuBUVQVHu22jQhn7wJmzbdk4Zd5LHGx/IMG_8854.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmP1CsJhqb6nmcYoq8upZkMqHH2J49b2Je5hMYTJKkezmh/IMG_8854.JPG\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmRx7CN9s2FPjsWAiSHc4gQGRnw8ksrS4PjWpnqUDik7G1/IMG_8857.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmRRZAYdJwJ5CUz2ww7BSGDFa36aHxqaK5FGACa4EWNGVn/IMG_8864.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmVNmDRU5uzQhTTmD3S6E8dY74D7xCviRinRAwxjpxEppn/IMG_8868.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmSrW5U3dLcJitYQ5j3aex8fQyDy3YAndPA2za1AgqPjuk/IMG_7388%202.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmeqT61aPj96uXdBM6V39vdAhzAhjvX99zsC1k7qCugoDT/IMG_7647%203.jpeg\",\"https://images.hive.blog/DQmYq7cnKjo8nZR7ETTuEfGG8Nv4hkdGdBrP2K6aovBixpz/IMG_7391%202.jpeg\"],\"tags\":[\"life\",\"lifestyle\",\"writing\",\"family\",\"photography\",\"garden\",\"homestead\"],\"users\":[\"s0u1\"]}",

        "body": "I know we don't really have a homestead per se. It was, by and large, a holiday home when we bought the property and we've learned a lot about the history in the time we've lived here.\n![1D04C907-7103-4F32-BCAC-E8CF884111FD_4_5005_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmW6C4xDBEkVmqBGj6FvpcgaUG6zKU4UbQmX8j9nL1XZx1/1D04C907-7103-4F32-BCAC-E8CF884111FD_4_5005_c.jpeg)\n*The house as advertised by the estate agent*\n\nFor example, the house was built in the 1970s and had 4 bedrooms, with two garages under the house. The drive sloped down to the access to the garages and the back of the house is two-storeys. The property has a 'Périgordian' roof which is traditional construction for the area.\n\n![1F6AFBCC-C304-4D89-A316-C5E74F4A877F_4_5005_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmaSohsBvLidJsFcSbP6CrTS1EHFPJdR5s8YG8jMq9WPBc/1F6AFBCC-C304-4D89-A316-C5E74F4A877F_4_5005_c.jpeg)\n\n\nThe outside of the house doesn't seem to have changed since it was built, but now it has 3 bedrooms and one of the garages has been converted into a 1 bedroom apartment with a lovely bathroom. We altered the apartment around a little to lose the living room area and add a double bedroom area. This is a temporary measure, closed off by curtains. This means a family, or friends that don't mind sharing can come to stay and have the relatively private space downstairs. \nThe curtained-off double bedroom is also easier to make and keep warm in winter.\n\n![2FD009E6-22DB-44A4-AE27-1824851BD2F6_4_5005_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVYVPraAqBto7QwRusTpavA2wpD2E8Eb1LMvbde88BCGU/2FD009E6-22DB-44A4-AE27-1824851BD2F6_4_5005_c.jpeg)\n\n![53CF9618-1CAA-4203-8BB0-5EBCA495457D_4_5005_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmdDjQRq4vGWGuw88m7VLWCkFYgVy8rkhcUpJUqxNNNVMr/53CF9618-1CAA-4203-8BB0-5EBCA495457D_4_5005_c.jpeg)\n\n\n![1B26909A-D0D4-4E51-96D1-7F29AD16675B_4_5005_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTM8W1FXgnNwhwQSgHz1PQFWfCoVjgcUHS3MABk9FSVUi/1B26909A-D0D4-4E51-96D1-7F29AD16675B_4_5005_c.jpeg)\n\n\n![image.png](https://images.hive.blog/DQmd9ktW8VnoPBxt5xBzX6pFEgnC9y4i4ATY7HdUUooLuMe/image.png)\n*Cozy*\n\n![94EF8845-F944-4ED2-9D52-35D0CF5FBC5F_4_5005_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmQYhcazFyPgn7VYWk9gXRH4PE2kVT1L1xVhVpMdQsUg9v/94EF8845-F944-4ED2-9D52-35D0CF5FBC5F_4_5005_c.jpeg)\n\nTo the South side of the property is a field and a barn. We did some work on the barn when we first arrived and had a concrete floor installed. This means we can use it eventually for stables if we want to.\nWe've fenced off the barn so the horses can graze without getting into trouble.\n\n![A8519973-FCB5-4A42-9884-5D6AF1EECCA5_4_5005_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmWed3siziXT8u1xEhcTHewEJVpnkdJusk7Xkzmxb8y5uS/A8519973-FCB5-4A42-9884-5D6AF1EECCA5_4_5005_c.jpeg)\n\nThat field and the barn itself were part of a large purchase by the previous owners. They seemed to buy-up parcels of land that bordered their property in order to prevent someone else building on their view. It has benefitted us and we consider ourselves fortunate.\n\nThe Vineyard Paddock across the road is (we believe) another part of their purchasing strategy. The vineyards in the whole of this area of France failed in the 1950s although the remnants of the vineyard here can still be seen. We have a few tendrils growing in the woods and some of the furrows used for the vines remain.\n\nSo far, we have planted fruit trees in the orchard, tended and maintained the woodland across the road, cut grass, made hay, built a greenhouse and a henhouse and renovated an old, ramshackle field shelter. The ongoing work of mending fences takes up a lot of time and making new fences is another big job we take on in lumps here and there.\n\n\n![DF24E6B5-4949-466A-B25B-CE49FA1BE28D_1_105_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbZd8NpRHDxvxb9w1EqrXtL84nMPAm1rW8gi59ABnUzqF/DF24E6B5-4949-466A-B25B-CE49FA1BE28D_1_105_c.jpeg)\n\n\n![D472D52B-AECA-4D4F-93C5-5E7FBCE31522_4_5005_c.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXEfNPgD56B38W68yRwJ8H3yGjxz5avpp2CugtPDUBdua/D472D52B-AECA-4D4F-93C5-5E7FBCE31522_4_5005_c.jpeg)\n\nThe last few days have been spent making a fence to stop the horses from trampling on the new and unstable bank on the front of the field shelter. The area has already grassed itself and I planted blackberry/bramble roots when they were uprooted during some of the work we've done so far. Not all of the roots survived, but, knowing the tenacious nature of bramble, I have no doubt it will spread.\nI planted the roots along the bank for a couple of reasons. The first was to try to stabilise the newly-deposited earth, the second was to discourage the horses as they are heavy and will destabilise the ground more and the third is for the fruit - not necessarily for our use, the wildlife are welcome to eat the fruits when they eventually arrive.\n\n![2AAA8569-82EC-43A6-8ABC-FE4C73924692.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYZZPCBpaEmKWWhEeKSSqh4YRt3Ss4jhT45Se4BymJei4/2AAA8569-82EC-43A6-8ABC-FE4C73924692.jpeg)\n\n**The Project: Renovate Field Shelter for use as shelter, Tack Room and Hay storage**\n\n![FE889E9B-ED23-46EE-B247-9BA3E011E199_1_201_a.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbNQc9qqchAUJrDc6YT52vjno8ssjYwiFHNxR4Baiwyjm/FE889E9B-ED23-46EE-B247-9BA3E011E199_1_201_a.jpeg)\n*Short clip of ponies with original ramshackle field shelter in background*\n\nHalf of the fence posts were put in place when the ground was prepared for the renovation of the field shelter. Those posts were pushed into the ground by the driver of the mini-excavator (our son). I hammered more stabilising posts at the top of the bank to try to ensure the earth didn't move as we worked on it all.\n\nThe last two days have been spent putting the boards in place (after sourcing them from our woodpile), putting in extra posts between the original ones and fitting the boards and top rails to make sure the horses can graze on the bank, but not get onto the bank.\n![stables 2.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmadQQk8HBucrw9NAqepzUtNhBmtiQFJFry6wWHxzMsYst/stables%202.jpeg)\n*First fence to enclose the stable yard*\n\n![03F27B0A-0AAC-4EA9-95AE-2808D2BAE224.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmc2NrpDRbrWAh7LNeviqRbUZRUNrLkRVRseAV8JdpDi2r/03F27B0A-0AAC-4EA9-95AE-2808D2BAE224.jpeg)\n\n\n![185D937C-71B5-4B75-9FB8-79F6BE2F3F78.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZiYdz1RAsmeT5KyFFZNWMS4RjquhbTT8eKH3tckMTyoD/185D937C-71B5-4B75-9FB8-79F6BE2F3F78.jpeg)\n*Quite a steep bank*\n\n![27A98FEC-2A5B-47B7-9D6F-8332300BB7F6.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYmyzYMEns3sZL45HvUQFZxEJAH1x7hpBPvbqrrhbiP3p/27A98FEC-2A5B-47B7-9D6F-8332300BB7F6.jpeg)\n*Someone has a new chainsaw*\n*ME! It's me! I have a new chainsaw!*\n\n\n![B8DD7F1C-6918-4DCA-BFD1-DA5AADA0346C.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmdy6Xg6b6Wz1ftUNrL9mjucHzKtawrF6kXzvkHKw3175w/B8DD7F1C-6918-4DCA-BFD1-DA5AADA0346C.jpeg)\n*Almost there*\n\n![stables pics1.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmdR3xVC7nn8BgA57u6rk6xCBesDpw1ot66oFrojpBrtSk/stables%20pics1.jpeg)\n*Grass mowed*\n\n![Stables pics.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmS6p5Mk4g1Zf9pNAdM12gXjMiSvV7xdEqHxMNCT3Q62Ws/Stables%20pics.jpeg)\n*I think we're just about done. I'll put a sun shade, table and chairs on the grass and watch nature pass by*\n\nNext week will be a lot of hard work, we're hoping to get a field of hay cut, dried, tedded and brought in!",

        "body": "The wildlife here in France is shy. We’ve seen boar and deer, hares, rabbits and hawks but not managed to capture any on video, mainly because the sightings have been unexpected and over very quickly.\n\nHaving said that, I do have a few pictures to share. I'm no botanist and a lot of the flowers and plants are unknown to me, so bear with me when I can't identify them. If you know what they are, I'd appreciate the knowledge.\n\n![3D86BA1A-C384-4BD5-95DB-F58E471882BB.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbWgmPyaukVjGLapExcNGAYx65t8HE2UW6VW5sDaPTea8/3D86BA1A-C384-4BD5-95DB-F58E471882BB.jpg)\n*I was worried this was ragwort to start with. It has similar flowers, but the leaves are not the same.*\n\n![6A7F56DD-0C99-4F6C-BDBE-62372CC2C955.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYBWtcFWpaQzZYA952CLcFBapYhzMWVae1L6nba5fkhQ6/6A7F56DD-0C99-4F6C-BDBE-62372CC2C955.jpg)\n*I looked this up and I think it's an 'Octopus fungus'. Very weird, found in woodland*\n\n![682AFA75-746F-4348-B959-85C8F5CE8FAA.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmb5DingRadVx64ELgJk4pgKk6XAcpAe5ie5baPgkovwDM/682AFA75-746F-4348-B959-85C8F5CE8FAA.jpg)\n\n\n![AC85AAAF-7531-4318-B9D2-EA8751DC00F1.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTU3tZUpEGegzRTs3RTeCzbDdEoT8zqYKz58sn4azXHFZ/AC85AAAF-7531-4318-B9D2-EA8751DC00F1.jpeg)\n*I don't know what this is called, but it grows as a dusty-pink colour. It doesn't photosynthesise like other plants, instead, it gets nutrients from the roots of other plants. It's a parasitic plant, a bit like mistletoe*\n\n![A371D0DC-262D-4331-B24E-2EB5923947CA.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmWogbdibdeaNLKpPgAaJtZ5wzrtZbSn3Rj4wmpdHdPYJe/A371D0DC-262D-4331-B24E-2EB5923947CA.jpeg)\n*This delicate little flower is a violet, possibly a Field Violet. We have lots of this flower in the bottom of the field where it's always damp.*\n\n\n![E9127A69-1031-451F-B18D-869351E6C6E7.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVdBycuhJGDShLDRoF3mH7j5RVV5nznzGEivg3MYaUxFq/E9127A69-1031-451F-B18D-869351E6C6E7.jpeg)\n*This unusual creature is a spotless ladybird or 'ladybug' for our American audience. I have no idea how it got its name - I'll probably disappear off into an insect rabbit hole later today, to research why it's called 'Ladybird/bug'*\n\n![E79629F5-5243-4549-B2F5-59BE77FCF54B.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYDJF4sfpZJ5f3uWbGqUpHwkJF4dJm9SYmBme8pLn9Jvy/E79629F5-5243-4549-B2F5-59BE77FCF54B.jpeg)\n*I think this is a Swallow. We have a few flitting around the stables, making their usual nests. They're really busy little birds and we look forward to seeing them every year.*\n\n![7CD8E6DE-1FCC-4920-916E-7C7FEBF4E436.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZ4GZVEH1e3NAPz5zPnwsGwqQccVTtFBubdouVCug9i9T/7CD8E6DE-1FCC-4920-916E-7C7FEBF4E436.jpg)\n\n\n![D68974FF-4E6C-4C82-9892-52757CFF3971.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmepvffJ4sSbBzt38t1RSCKsPbCzndRZLD7sGDW2Nu6jN4/D68974FF-4E6C-4C82-9892-52757CFF3971.jpeg)\n*I have no idea what this flower is. I bought one in a pot last year and it thrived and spread.*\n\n![8B0574B0-6BCF-4940-9B43-F1382E8B266C.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbuok8iuTuSc8MYHaLDnYDaXG5mj59ET4MywHadyCzuBG/8B0574B0-6BCF-4940-9B43-F1382E8B266C.jpeg)\n*Carpenter bee. They're large and noisy, but they are so beautiful, black, shiny and almost metallic-looking*\n\n![85A7B345-D95F-4D76-92AE-9981D4B4C324.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmQjMRSECVTpveDR8Ekij19Lu4B9mmxxwPVrBxKysnu1cw/85A7B345-D95F-4D76-92AE-9981D4B4C324.jpg)\n\n\n![209187A3-578D-4D65-B209-ECE54ABCC325.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXLZGr6VEVPnF7rXCLYVHjuBjp2iPjqAvWzCwzZSXaqVg/209187A3-578D-4D65-B209-ECE54ABCC325.jpeg)\n*Apologies for the terrible image quality. It was dusk, the subject was far away and I had to zoom in to even get this picture. A few moments later, this owl dropped into the garden and flew off with something for its supper.*\n\n![344CE2F5-A3BA-49D3-AE94-140E993B622F.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmeS2w1wi2THYiwa3J4UxvWPLixmv3QqbfArfhbpMUuqgg/344CE2F5-A3BA-49D3-AE94-140E993B622F.jpeg)\n*This mushroom has collected water. I seem to think it's known as an 'apple mushroom', but don't hold me to that.*\n\n![5C28DEB7-6D92-405E-A54E-2D7D018715AB.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmfZYuozMvZdhgTNqa2JaFLVfxzqCchg8nsnsuzaC84NdU/5C28DEB7-6D92-405E-A54E-2D7D018715AB.jpg)\n\n\n![1030F693-13F1-4D0C-9BB4-EFC5E0396B61.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZLLqanjYFgTkXpHMkLhoaCKKwJrtdiqbroW636pcDvyc/1030F693-13F1-4D0C-9BB4-EFC5E0396B61.jpeg)\n*Part of our property was a vineyard mid-20th century. All the vineyards failed around the 1950s and farmers turned to growing walnuts as their main crop. The 'bare bones' of the vineyard can still be seen in the woodlands, straight rows and furrows where the vines once grew. Some survived, obviously, and can be seen in the hedgerows that border the woods*\n\n![00EA9AFC-B787-4071-BEE2-6A95B073C5EF.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZ2ezbqTiKZb5R5Td4f5cx2qcSEkzRfFEmRPifMpYtNKq/00EA9AFC-B787-4071-BEE2-6A95B073C5EF.jpg)\n\n![E8750743-FAD1-42C4-9E3D-57550A12D0DC.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVRuSHJuzSrMiEssKCb7AkvjqDh8ZoDYJk3eBynk26CbE/E8750743-FAD1-42C4-9E3D-57550A12D0DC.jpg)\n\n![86E1CD1B-189F-4AE1-A4A2-4F326945B10F.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZRMS6ArcncVEyKwia4hCQvhQZwKFzwG56nLj6n5UNKMW/86E1CD1B-189F-4AE1-A4A2-4F326945B10F.jpg)\n\n![D3D82E0C-5B93-4F68-BBC5-4EDEFA44862F.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmdvyTjbGVicHJJtpVHonDXASS7CMNjinVPJB9qYz9cAuW/D3D82E0C-5B93-4F68-BBC5-4EDEFA44862F.jpg)\n*Wild roses also grow in the hedgerows. And we have Blackthorn too. Blackthorn fruit are sloes, an ancient ancestor of the plum*\n\n![0D579393-AC2D-4FFC-AC4A-7B7F2F0BC70D.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUzJqXDqML2UqoEX25kJCvjfq9XgAhYL2ZxVpXP4jxE6C/0D579393-AC2D-4FFC-AC4A-7B7F2F0BC70D.jpeg)\n*This tiny spider was transporting something when I spotted it. As you can see, the grass is difficult for it to cross. I watched it for a little while and I think it's carrying an egg sac.*\n\n![C41F7829-BE03-4E47-9CF4-AC53C29EC13D.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmS7fjLixnu9VUFEedr1DnSAQJdsSUcx7127TadZvGGwHS/C41F7829-BE03-4E47-9CF4-AC53C29EC13D.jpeg)\n*The kestrel is nesting in the barn again and it chases the buzzards off. We put lights on this tree at Christmas time, but haven't managed to get a star up there. Maybe the kestrel will take it up there this winter?*\n\n![A286B767-BAC8-4186-9BB6-1DDB85496E3B.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYmqai28kXkQSjBn5mdbKPjXm5theBn1ozi5snnTrLeVn/A286B767-BAC8-4186-9BB6-1DDB85496E3B.jpg)\n*We have raptors here, birds of prey that whirl and swoop over the fields. Red-tailed Kites often fly overhead. I think my chickens are safe, as they're too big for the kite to manage*\n\n![233E7E91-0CA4-4E6C-9EA9-83768F861DB4.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmdx5qNfmGHYQCX4pTKmbihX5qzFxpVjTFdHKa1igc8ULD/233E7E91-0CA4-4E6C-9EA9-83768F861DB4.jpg)\n\n\n![6809CFD2-426F-4A3E-846D-80E4B66BE643.poster.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmRGaFv1hfGjanxsdaNRJCmFeV5SkLVV4w5JFMH7S2znnc/6809CFD2-426F-4A3E-846D-80E4B66BE643.poster.JPG)\n*This is a still from a video. I'll get it uploaded to Youtube in another post.\n\n\n![A77EB383-B1E2-4BD0-9B24-6DE2D1A40F79.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmX5GGq9CSN1MZiDNmrmro28AXUy1gbfJXWNSpQ4bUCyor/A77EB383-B1E2-4BD0-9B24-6DE2D1A40F79.jpg)\n*This little guy was rescued from the pool. He's one of the bigger lizards we get here*\n\n\n![EF32370E-EAA1-4D46-B229-3A13FFE5A6D6.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTzwiMnkotRD2vmVA5ZvVM7VdCei4hstgiAgteGj9wvdJ/EF32370E-EAA1-4D46-B229-3A13FFE5A6D6.jpg)\n*This is one of the smaller lizards.*\n\n\n![2D966859-B502-4FE1-8CB3-45B056BE277F.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmeDU3hrhixjA6VHv22k5VMLLkmktcbdfHaJgAmZgNowd8/2D966859-B502-4FE1-8CB3-45B056BE277F.jpg)\n*This horrible creature is a 'Flatfly' and the females have saw-like mouth-parts with which to cut into an animal's flesh. They need the blood to make their eggs and the poor horses go through it with these flies. They can also take a bite out of humans too, but they don't like the taste of their blood, so only bite once. The flies are really difficult to kill, they can take a good slap, return to the wound they made and carry on as though nothing happened. I wear gloves and one way of killing them is to slap the fly hard and, using a lot of weight behind your hand, rub the fly on the horse's neck to kill the fly. I also use ducktape to catch them. The sticky tape keeps hold of the fly, but be careful, the fly is strong enough to escape if you don't wrap it up quickly and kill it.*\n\n\n![EC54011D-F38A-4FE6-86CC-A5418C1E1023.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXd3YcWakTmXzsRxJzqf7cLKkWBspsGRnuAYWHjLwsahC/EC54011D-F38A-4FE6-86CC-A5418C1E1023.jpg)\n*Izzy the Lizard*\n\n![810993BE-650D-4DEB-9A6E-4C1FE33F3A0E.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbLwbCJCkRvHCM2YR8NZDztJspkfarj6D1BEEf6rMLc5f/810993BE-650D-4DEB-9A6E-4C1FE33F3A0E.jpg)\n*We get cute frogs inside the house too. They over-winter in the shelter of the door frames. When they begin to get active in the springtime, they are really noisy*\n\n![8656B7D2-53C0-4FDE-9EFB-ADC2A89E84B9.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUgVtp36jVfn6DvUUuG6wbz13jcxGqYoFHDugdoV7vCBH/8656B7D2-53C0-4FDE-9EFB-ADC2A89E84B9.jpg)\n\n![B59596D2-20C9-4049-9CB7-4290074CEB30.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmR4RkxF7nPtqTbbdDZdY6Z8hQ1aEPYbuRN3jU3t7eiQVS/B59596D2-20C9-4049-9CB7-4290074CEB30.jpg)\n*Not quite 'wildlife'. We have found a couple of skulls on our fields. Most recently, we found a young boar skull. I saved it, but Tora decided it would be a good toy and she left it on the drive, where it got crushed. The bones were not dense, unlike this deer and they started crumbling. The boar skull had teeth that had not yet erupted through the jawline.*\n\n![BF4706E9-5419-44E5-959E-A3FFAD869C6A.jpg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZSM6bSt7erE44qFna3q8Lgpen8KjYRyFSuXuM4Wt5MUF/BF4706E9-5419-44E5-959E-A3FFAD869C6A.jpg)\n*We get stinkbugs and these things. I don't know what they are, they don't bite or sting, but they don't fly well, either. The stinkbugs fly more by luck than judgement and only land when they crash into something.*\n\nI think this episode is enough for now. I'll post some more pictures at a later date.",

        "body": "A little bit of a weird title, I agree, but I can explain.\n\nSince moving here two years ago, I’ve spent at least part of every day simply looking into the sky. \n\n\n![3933A694-1309-4F1D-86DD-6EA5AB00DF4B.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmfViBxYfBu9x5fohYfMAUmSRYDCepAU4ALWHVhmQJZ1Ws/3933A694-1309-4F1D-86DD-6EA5AB00DF4B.jpeg)\n*Our new home*\n\nIf you’ve read Stephen King’s Dark Tower series, you may be familiar with The Wheel (bear with me, I may be wrong, it’s been a while since I read the series). King describes the world revolving around a wheel that is visible in the sky. I understood the concept, but never witnessed the phenomena until coming to live here, high in the hills in South/West France.\n\n\n![IMG_5918.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmSECor58H9HU2BrR1ypUAnBBeGxupNfDN2adeEEsFHyT8/IMG_5918.jpeg)\n*Our local airport*\n\n![IMG_5919.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmaXrS5JWbQ3i72SG34MCUywJunpHnbT6bCVxoX5m9JGYW/IMG_5919.jpeg)\n*Sky under the wings of the plane I travelled back to the UK on*\n\n![IMG_5920.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmeK3ENusc9khDYgWPSFQzKtcu4y5bcUe3gSnvAKpNrDSu/IMG_5920.jpeg)\n*I don't remember where this is! I can see a chalk-drawing on the hillside*\n\n![IMG_5928.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTNLrNUX6W4pn2V6VGJB3qjsnBJrki4NDy5q51i335q9K/IMG_5928.jpeg)\n*Low cloud or mist? I suppose that depends on your perspective. Down in the valley it could seem like low cloud, but up high, it's definitely misty. We are at 200m elevation - 656ft*\n\n![IMG_5916.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmPAiq4oTFDxMRxp1p4fFTtmBq2NPCct8LoPHx8DKsJ6Do/IMG_5916.jpeg)\nThe black spot at the top of the image is possibly a raptor. The cloud formation is definitely curved*\n\n![IMG_5930.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmcPMfBuxg57HbuH8Gz9E7pSWUJJbYqvHzoCo2t231ZJeb/IMG_5930.jpeg)\n*Sunrise at our home is a magical sight. I don't see it very often. The mist/low cloud effect is mesmerising*\n\n![IMG_5915.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZYr5iTZNeuxgjn51JhstrAq6ejGFmJoX43LDAzGD54BB/IMG_5915.jpeg)\n*Down below the lake, we have a patch of ground that takes ages to dry out. We've named this place 'Soggy Bottom'. There are no clouds to show the curved effect. I do love this view.*\n\n\n![IMG_6143.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmPbfL7FHoN77TzinCb5VaJg3Uuw9xiMS5V3Ao51y37qXf/IMG_6143.jpeg)\n*Sunset from the top of the field, just behind the field shelter*\n\n![IMG_7485.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmd1HrG9odFsNP2uDoMo8wnkn8AhenQTxttjHtbaRVP1ZP/IMG_7485.jpeg)\n*Across the valley*\n\n![IMG_7484.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmSgqUHvEA1xouidVUXM3YBMBo43SQQDw3agRLiLtmsD4G/IMG_7484.jpeg)\n*We're high up, but there are still some places that are higher*\n\n![IMG_7483.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZsUMyvF2GFyBotpaNmLaY1uZNMrLW15J93uXkLNeYoB6/IMG_7483.jpeg)\n*This is one of the aspects that sold the property to us when we visited that first time*\n\n![IMG_7481.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmWbY1tUMrR9FdsYvfzGWdD4faUVgkpjNoFZcjZcgW9X25/IMG_7481.jpeg)\n*Clouds casting shadows*\n\nIt’s almost as though you can see the curve of the world. The effect is especially clear when the sky is cloudy. The clouds seem to start from a point beyond the horizon and expand in a cone or segment of a wheel – sometimes it looks like a beam from a torch or flashlight shining across the sky.\n\n![IMG_9074.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmaLSC8VGp6Wf763MaQ1tfKkWdS7iktKZnaZGjGijkvTNE/IMG_9074.jpeg)\n*I love the sunsets here. They are awe inspiring and give a perspective that we are a tiny speck on this planet*\n\n![IMG_9080.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXdeu7oviFEYnLcQuhhqcTSNRzqoosj5kSX3bXiNsZ1Ue/IMG_9080.jpeg)\n*Now we're getting the effect*\n\n![IMG_9079.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmcLqbBd4BYcEDXvncBZDJSjp6Xro2DBfC9wTb7TdRGY9o/IMG_9079.jpeg)\n\n![IMG_9078.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmNW33d67wWkCBFGLVuDZqt58qcQ3FUphwFr5gEDoDCBEQ/IMG_9078.jpeg)\n\n![IMG_9077.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbhBypMpBrvhfZtuMZgvjdXMako4EHxUh2pLyM8QDJdVs/IMG_9077.jpeg)\n*I think this shows the effect I'm trying to explain*\n\n![IMG_9076.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmezgTrcKmAvBddsKhovc1AhgUx5TnU4iUbuTry3j7htus/IMG_9076.jpeg)\n*The sky expands outwards. It's not the camera, this is the same effect I see with the naked eye*\n\n![IMG_9075.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZBYWU8FZmRvkMVEbizmgN39JsDZ5oB2xLj9ddSwVp4aJ/IMG_9075.jpeg)\n*I sometimes feel so small when I look up. Sometimes I can experience a sense of vertigo*\n\n\nI’m not sure if I can capture the effect in my pictures and I have been looking back.\n\nI have spent a lot of time in the main bathroom on the back of the house. No, not because I’m a clean-freak or that I have tummy problems, it’s simply because the view is spectacular!\n\nToday is Sunday and I’m a little stuck for time. The rules here prevent us making noise before 10am and after 12 mid-day and I would like to get out to get some work done before the time constraints kick in.\n\nSo, this is going to be a short-but-sweet post, filled with         "body": "![IMG_2378.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZRDniXk7NUtPfWpCbbzk7VSQRzRipuAxdMLhrHmCbyav/IMG_2378.jpeg)\n\nThe first question we ask of each other in the morning, and one of the last ‘proper’ questions asked at the end of the day, revolves around the work we need to do for the progression or maintenance of our new home.\n\nThis morning’s “What are we doing today?” question resulted in a grin for me.\n\nWe’re going into the woods across the road to cut down some of the trees we identified yesterday as dead. \n\n![IMG_2706.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUyt72ybmuW9u5r9FnKk1TY2kqxqc1T5MQciC4q1wFpWx/IMG_2706.jpeg)\n\n\nWe need posts and rails for fences, posts for a windbreak for the field shelter, and a couple of longer posts to enable us to erect a tarpaulin for additional shade for the summer.\n\n\n![IMG_2510.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmS2U3K8uk7Rqar482Pd3c3C1hFc1qddaWdowp8R1256UX/IMG_2510.jpeg)\n\n![IMG_2509.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmW5dncPKXyVEnEm2do66Qci9poJUgu9ZogVan2JKE9bNa/IMG_2509.jpeg)\n\n\nMy level of strength is increasing and @s0u1 bought an electric chainsaw just for my own use as it’s not as heavy as the petrol (gas) driven models, nor does it need the same amount of effort to start it. It’s definitely the way forward!\n\n\n![Chainsaw.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUaqMUV5U4sdBY2JWCZDJxCr4dLy9bXqiHLro1We3ZLsL/Chainsaw.jpeg)\n\n\nIn the late winter/early spring of this year, with the help of our friends, Gail & Tommo, we took down a number of dead trees to use as firewood. \n\n\n![image.png](https://images.hive.blog/DQmeS1TzviXh8YyMcs21dijUbiZU3wFkNqi4wfjYiQSmdS3/image.png)\n\n\nI honestly believed we’d not need to do so much work in that particular woodland this year, but it seems I was wrong. Yesterday’s inspection showed we’ve lost a number of trees and to get the best use out of them, we need to take them down and utilise them for fencing.\n\nProgression with the jobs we’d like to do to improve the property has to be tempered by the jobs we need to do to maintain the property, so mix & match. We could do all the jobs we *want* to do, and that would be fun and satisfying, but then the maintenance jobs would become overwhelming. ‘A stitch in time, saves nine’ is an important part of maintenance. Leaving maintenance to the last minute is not an efficient use of time or effort. Mending something properly and in a timely manner is better than replacing it – in terms of monetary cost, as well as effort.\n\n![IMG_2461.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXtEMj4gwgfVM9dCcAiysECwukZPrPDS5zSw5pEQAwEgf/IMG_2461.jpeg)\n*Jobs we NEED to do - mow Lake View Paddock*\n\n![IMG_2460.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmSEApF9wrtubmiaBF24cKGeZuGBoztsiAukNpRwUnGD58/IMG_2460.jpeg)\n*Jobs we WANT to do*\n\nThe horses need to be kept safe and well and if a fence is down, it needs repairing immediately, or we could have a similar problem to the one last year, where two of our horses escaped into the neighbour’s field and out onto the road.\n\n\n![IMG_2486.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmScbipequTGrM1diq5iodHowczX9CgyPbJtMZ4hq6LBXi/IMG_2486.jpeg)\n*Keeping the 3 Amigos safe is priority*\n\nThe field shelter was given a little try-out yesterday. We let the horses into the compound to take a look at what we’ve been doing. They were wary and a little scared, very jumpy and skittish, but I think it will work very well when we’ve completed the work.\n\n\n![IMG_2740.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmR2HpPDwQDZNH7Sw9Txu3k2EW5gZ55Tnjc4ePsNiyepva/IMG_2740.jpeg)\n*Onyx refused to enter  the shelter*\n\n![IMG_2739.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmburUzbQjjgpkEENdBtsk5ddZckoumXoJrnPzLJraQfkv/IMG_2739.jpeg)\n\n\nI’m hoping to get the field shelter finished and ready for them to move in to before the full summer arrives. \n\nThe shelter will perform a few duties. Shelter for the horses by way of two compartments, with rain, wind and sun protection, water and feeding stations, a tack-room where their feed and equipment can be stored, and a hay store to make everything easy to manage.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/shorts/-Akx-AdYB7w\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/shorts/IGtJU5znvCA\n\nWe need a few things to make this work. The hay needs to be square-baled which means we have to buy an old-style baler. These are not easy to come by as the farmers have moved on to the large 400kg-600kg round bales and those bales are too heavy for our mini-tractor to manage on the slope we work on. \n\nIf we can find one, that would be perfect, but then we’d need to borrow or buy a bigger tractor.\n\nOr we can make a rudimentary baler and hand-bale the hay. This option is possible and though it would take time and manual effort, it can be done. Watch this space.\n\nFor the last two years, we have cut and dried the hay manually – and when I say ‘manually’ I mean with the bare minimum mechanical aids. \n\n\n![IMG_5742.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmRaDsRmTHxvjJFeqVt2V54XSJyrfdzZY7VEfyQ6ceKhUL/IMG_5742.jpeg)\n*Hot, dusty and hard work*\n\n![IMG_5744.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmP4RoTriiZYBswmJ1GqYPBC1gXgo4V83CjdB9qXoBUigY/IMG_5744.jpeg)\n*Builder's bags will take 1 Tonne of hardcore etc*\n\n![IMG_5743.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZMi4yCRhzBAvk5eqGyvPhboLwK11SqVRtaLBAkcdqdF5/IMG_5743.jpeg)\n*Using hand tools the first year*\n\nThe first year, we cut the hay on the small field (Vineyard Paddock) with the tractor mower, turned it to make sure it was dry using pitchforks and brought in around 22 bags (1 Tonne builder’s bags) stuffed with hay. We only managed a small part of the big field, that first year.\n\nThe second year, we brought in the Vineyard Paddock’s hay using the tractor mower and the newly-purchased ‘Tedder’ – a device towed behind the tractor which turns the cut grass and stacks it in long lines called ‘Windrows’. We also collected more hay from the big field just behind the Vineyard Paddock in the same way and that made the first time we didn’t have to buy additional hay for the horses.\n\nThis year, we possibly have the Vineyard Paddock, the big field, the Dordogne Field and Lake View Paddock to collect from and so the baler would be a great help for the storage.\n![IMG_7620.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmNfiqXTCPbKHS9DgYuFkX8CW5rLnt98QQurcMF1FXE6ZU/IMG_7620.jpeg)\n*Big field*\n\n![IMG_7624.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXtEb7PstyLDoue923FDE5F7JgUpPCpVBL8RekTH5oizV/IMG_7624.jpeg)\n*First cut*\n\n![IMG_7634 2.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVPFQDdBLhPTXQJeWJgLaGAyiZWisRQWx6UpV1o7XKJtL/IMG_7634%202.jpeg)\n*Part done*\n\n![IMG_7636 2.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmWFrWeiSrJAiHyGpN6mqRQiQh4aR7o5k6PCbosx14WUCd/IMG_7636%202.jpeg)\n*It's a BIG field!*\n\n![IMG_7645 2.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUNggkREAfHJ6js3S8GeW8kJJ7uK32ZuDzrSmzW6mqC15/IMG_7645%202.jpeg)\n*We got a system going*\n\n![IMG_7646.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmReEzoPfkLreX8WKyayNhLdL4AW3bix66GCvRxswHy6BV/IMG_7646.jpeg)\n*Big boots and hand tools in scorching weather!*\n\n\n![IMG_7684 2.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTffFGHbn5o3HBZrVRNLGxxFqnmT8iMQXTwZTFoejuomp/IMG_7684%202.jpeg)\n*The home-made hand-baler*\n\n\n\nAs an aside, we keep @s0u1’s mum up to date with everything we do in daily phone calls. She just had her 99th birthday. Her father was the Fire Chief when she was a girl and she told us to make double-sure that the hay was completely dry before putting it indoors. She remembers her father being called out regularly during hay-making time because slightly damp hay can heat up to the point where it combusts and that was when the barn fires started.\n\n![IMG_7391.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYq7cnKjo8nZR7ETTuEfGG8Nv4hkdGdBrP2K6aovBixpz/IMG_7391.jpeg)\n*A lot of hay!*\n\nOn her advice, @s0u1 bought a long thermometer that sticks in the hay and monitors the temperature.\n\nThe hay will be brought in and stored in the barn, baled manually and then transported to the field shelter for storage. That way, we can bale the hay whenever possible and it won’t get dampened by rain or dew.\n\nI’m just having a coffee and then we’ll start the day’s work.\n\nI keep reminding myself: We Live Here!",

        "body": "As part of the condition of living here, we have to apply for a visa every year. This morning, we locked up the house, leaving Tora inside on her own, got in the car and drove 90 mins or so to the city.\n\nI always message our children to let them know we’re out and about on a long journey, just in case anything dreadful happens. Tora is alone in the house and if anything dreadful did happen to us, she would be in a terrible state, needing human intervention.\n\nWe got to the town around 20 minutes early and horror of horrors! The whole city centre was in a state of disrepair! Diversion signs everywhere, roadworks, traffic moving slowly through the narrow streets, plus there was a funfair set up (I don’t know why, it was probably agreed before the work was planned).\n\nRound and round we went, following the Google map directions. Eventually, we parked and walked to the Prefecture where our visas awaited us picking them up. We would have been dead on time, but there was a queue and so, we were a few moments later than our appointment time. Rather than sending us away because we'd missed the appointment, we were called right in and sat down for the process of renewing our visas.\n\nEveryone is polite and friendly and it really is lovely. Even if they can’t help you, they’re at the very least, polite.\n\nThe woman that sorted out our new visas agreed with me that ‘Brexit is tres, tres, tres terrible’ and we’re sorted for another year!\n\nOn our way back, we took a little more time and had a look at the work being done.\n\nThere is new paving going down and it looks to be constructed of marble.\n\nThe workmanship is incredibly intricate.\n\n\n![IMG_2668.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbr74YviqUzuzKJCgF38xYy3bvfWwV5nSqKnz3kX31wbN/IMG_2668.JPG)\n*Perfectly straight lines*\n\n![IMG_2672.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmeyvXvyNvqf3ooRPtqjjFBTe8UAxQiJrDHNo7GFgP1oV5/IMG_2672.JPG)\n*This will be a planted area*\n\n\n![IMG_2674.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmU4uvF8cfGVBcmxup8TXQVJvMu9HmHDoxKxCdd8H3ZckJ/IMG_2674.JPG)\n*So accurate*\n\n![IMG_2675.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmRRHXc4rf3qEJ9HoVXyQJm5nBnUpjSStcpEtD666e9vYE/IMG_2675.JPG)\n\n![IMG_2676.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmao6BPw64bkBeXNGV3CZTZ1r6JEgeF9FE56R64Qb2untE/IMG_2676.JPG)\n\n![IMG_2680.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUrXd7iw9TyAN7Wkbb7yTMk9n8iyASegVEcM3JZhHHE7W/IMG_2680.JPG)\n*How it started*\n\n\n![IMG_2685.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmZCLGbery8tRPp9A7v6Li9d1Cd4kvskWSbkT5wbGF6Jy6/IMG_2685.JPG)\n*Big chunky pieces of marble*\n\n![IMG_2687.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXdtmoa8ESdePeg6uBuBp2ZHjb8mzq6HgYtuDqHMBGonE/IMG_2687.JPG)\n*Not going to lie, if this was left by the side of the road in England, it would be 'liberated' overnight!*\n\n![IMG_2688.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmW6gs2jBk4W2dQGQv2AnmPsd7kf3aqSxqnnovu9GmFWnf/IMG_2688.JPG)\n*Bags full of pieces of pre-cut marble*\n\n---\n\nOnce we arrived back home, I messaged our children, fussed the frantic Tora who had been locked up in terrible conditions for at least three months, two weeks, six days and twenty three hours and then we had lunch.\n\nWe’ve just been to England and travelled back, had a day or so, then took our visitors to the same airport we’d just flown in to and to be honest, we’re a bit shattered by it all. I honestly feel jet-lagged, even though the time difference is one hour. \n\nWe’ve had a leisurely lunch and decided to have a walk in the woods as a relaxing pastime.\n\n\n![IMG_2697.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUMZRm5rgU8S6gYwD2uxgYCsVeKTdzjnjor6FwKd4oEZu/IMG_2697.JPG)\n*One dead tree*\n\n![IMG_2698.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXDFieiskNHswFDn7S4YSfKrczmTpKRGrFXBrFc61eh6o/IMG_2698.JPG)\n*And another*\n\n![IMG_2699.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmRcLVZ3NUCPtMGWSwsD9nZDdXeUBHEe2dQ95PdmHHJFGk/IMG_2699.JPG)\n*At least two pine trees and an oak or birch*\n\n![IMG_2700.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYCjkyq5v5PLgHF3wMvp7zeNq2cEtGbxTZeyNdnMitE1L/IMG_2700.JPG)\n*Pine*\n\n![IMG_2701.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTkeNX3cY96Jha7A5ffrxo2SmNqFznFSeDfKz8dijUQq8/IMG_2701.JPG)\n*That mini-chainsaw is not up to the task*\n\n![IMG_2702.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmb1aXdfUenhW8GVGxGWxkaZDqcBHULExXg13T7rixZq4q/IMG_2702.JPG)\n*Weird growth*\n\nWe walked into the woods with a clear sense of receiving peace and tranquillity, and walked out with a list of jobs that need doing. The list is as long as my arm and includes, but is not exclusive to:\n\nFelling trees,\nChopping wood,\nMaking planks,\nMaking poles,\nSplitting logs, \nClearing debris,\n\n![IMG_2703.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUB8ApXC1AM5anGch1rVNYaAxx7bXroqZYd3Twr83FRtY/IMG_2703.JPG)\n*One downed tree*\n\n![IMG_2704.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVPJo21Cy7JbTo6pAk81nJ17AoiW6AAUiPrPwLxktGLW3/IMG_2704.JPG)\n*The pines have really gone through it this year*\n\n![IMG_2705.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYEwmcaDWB6Ea66zTyqtxFZ4jGBwUskweNaacYU1BvXQt/IMG_2705.JPG)\n*It's best to get them down so they don't fall down and cause more damage or injure some unsuspecting person/creature*\n\n![IMG_2706.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUyt72ybmuW9u5r9FnKk1TY2kqxqc1T5MQciC4q1wFpWx/IMG_2706.JPG)\n\n![IMG_2707.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmdJCTDDyRcMgyGSD3MXhqUkxHatuYtiG71DArVvA53Yq6/IMG_2707.JPG)\n*This one just needs work. We'll be trimming the dead branches off*\n\n![IMG_2708.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYwWoiCeZZkGTED2bwSczooZQm4NBPbeHQtQYDTsEiMim/IMG_2708.JPG)\n*Downed tree*\n\n![IMG_2709.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXXGVX1maQkprp37rDnaSky7Va1E1fcTzL7ptAjZ1BJ5B/IMG_2709.JPG)\n*Branch trimming needed*\n\n![IMG_2710.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmWAasZLoQGkq9ZkhAdo6cfi2P37jHJfUtCAW3rZn1SdDw/IMG_2710.JPG)\n\n![IMG_2711.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUQs1RGDCPVr2C9dT76Y7Nq6irBhq5UGLgTig16aeJS4q/IMG_2711.JPG)\n*Husband! @s0u1*\n\n![IMG_2712.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmRQLaQFk2UP4kyewJag81Wvz5KzNycadgEYq6ZpcQDtDR/IMG_2712.JPG)\n*This is the Scottish Broom I wrote about yesterday. It's obviously dead, but despite the rain, it is tinder-dry and easy to set alight*\n\n\n![IMG_2720.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmdxsyLSZwFijA6zxjpA4CBba838qWjWywcShGQjFiym9B/IMG_2720.JPG)\n*Mushroom filled with rainwater*\n\n![IMG_2721.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmPraGrysninUFJ3BTohmRZfrfGx2P8Lp8Dg6oEifwbFeQ/IMG_2721.JPG)\n*Across the valley*\n\n![IMG_2723.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUgBhd8RJVsUqxsR9EFNQzQ1EkogMWaBiQ2g9kFDs9KHi/IMG_2723.JPG)\n*Our house (Behind the large fir trees)*\n\n![IMG_2724.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmS6oSwZkeCPQsqyvJo8Ca6JefgqcfGC3m12sYgpQHeaXg/IMG_2724.JPG)\n*Long grass, almost ready for cutting*\n\n![IMG_2725.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmezfgB3xrciLmfWq4cRwjDrF67QjRA2NRdwVSHEvC6cgB/IMG_2725.JPG)\n*Tora found a pond. We are at the top of a mountain (almost) and the ONLY water we have is rainwater. It is wet underfoot and we have random ponds, rivers and swamps*\n\n![IMG_2726.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQmabjPR7GGgCqHsRN4dRhMSGv5deXLvQYK3GjZVwX65YCa/IMG_2726.JPG)\n*Daisies bigger than the oaks! (Seedlings)*\n\n![IMG_2728.JPG](https://images.hive.blog/DQma3yr967tozG3LQJZFRdCbSSUYCs5DPrQRAqgC2wzasEH/IMG_2728.JPG)\n*Big pine cones! - not the biggest we have...*\n\nAnd breathe…\n\nIt’s all go in this slice of paradise and I am NOT complaining!\n\nIt's now definitely Wine O'Clock!",

        "body": "In the Dordogne/Corrèze part of France.\n\nIf you've followed my ramblings over the past few years, you may know that I now live in South-Western France. We chose this property for only a couple of reasons:\n\n1 The property comprises 28 acres or 11 hectares - 14 acres of grassland and 14 of woodland.\n\n2 The property was ready to move in to - a very fortunate part of the whole purchasing process as it turned out.\n\n3 The property has a pool.\n\nYes, those really were the three criteria we requested. \n\nWe wanted land for the horses - we weren't quite sure what work 28 acres entailed, but we now have a fair idea of how much work it is! We have enough land for grazing/resting and hay-making. The woodlands are an added bonus as we cut down dead trees (and 'harvest' fallen trees) for firewood and more recently, woodworking projects. \n\n![IMG_2286.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbdp5w3xFrqnfhGpn5crqLspxMdHcFDqxnGJgYWiCnTrA/IMG_2286.jpeg)\n*The reason we're here*\n\nWe started our move to France by looking at properties we could renovate and eventually move to when we retired. The diagnosis of cancer I received just 16 days after completing the house purchase gave us reason to think we had 'dropped lucky' when we upped our budget and went for a house that we could live in and do light renovation and improvement work at our leisure. We would not have been able to make the move if I had to live in a renovation project while recovering from the operation to remove the tumour.\n\nThe pool is self-explanatory.\n\nWe have been working on the property since moving in, we’ve had some help from friends and we’ve learned a lot.\n\nSo far, we have plans to build a balcony along the back of the house, put in a new kitchen and change the old kitchen to an en-suite bedroom as the main bedroom. This will look across the valley to the back of the house and afford us wonderful views every morning.\n\nI’d like a she-shed at some point, so I can sit and write and I’d love a tree house too, but I’m also aware of the work we already have to do as day-to-day running of the homestead.\n\nWe have fenced off a third of an acre for my vegetable garden (with greenhouse, shed and chickens) and we are building raised beds for the veggies.\n\n![IMG_6651.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmeeU2QoUZHJ9ED7Y4kqTrh9nnPRRGngGJrgBX8SUF6Mes/IMG_6651.jpeg)\n*View from the top*\n\n![IMG_6653.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmbAjk86RFTT6pW5dmQEAfJfhnB9xmxPC4QQCjCW8i3xnY/IMG_6653.jpeg)\n*Looking up the slope*\n\n![IMG_6658.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXFXHTHcTj4GAVnDTQe9krmWJXW7vJXjbkshzWFLZzeDd/IMG_6658.jpeg)\n*Starting the mow*\n\n![IMG_6661.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmT9FHgRhC4axiTY4c8LVU1rtQh6NJRVtfuxoNwPhLTEmo/IMG_6661.jpeg)\n*Almost finished!*\n\n\n![IMG_1824.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVHN2SF8yEY4P4mpBPwcWStXXEGLfQ74cRfpMibDgCT8P/IMG_1824.jpeg)\n*Filling the new bed*\n\n![IMG_1822.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmP2TaseZN64WsZk7JTGEmFa4Dp1VT2uzLvDYJMj8SJpVa/IMG_1822.jpeg)\n*Yes, that really is how steep the slope is*\n\n![IMG_1589.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmQcfZgBvvTRjPNM3SwiEj5newmkGUSjx6pR598CpGhvHK/IMG_1589.jpeg)\n*The beds filled with leaves*\n\n![IMG_1586.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmayM89oBRUFoT4dwzng6jkQnbTAGc4yzv9JCMY2SZaHjo/IMG_1586.jpeg)\n*More leaves*\n\n![IMG_1584.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmYrQh7RbgxF8dmuqUgg8hLf3UD5hsYX3JMRvgYh71ytvG/IMG_1584.jpeg)\n*So many leaves!*\n\nWe have repaired and renovated the field shelter that was here when we moved in. It was too low, ramshackle and in desperate need of repair and this year, in late winter/early spring, @s0u1 and our friend Tommo did the work of re-roofing and making the structure sound. Our son dug out the floor last September and things moved from there.\n\n![IMG_1724.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmaFYFYERChFQgV1pfcRMfUsvfgMD4KqvWmCdsR6Q8WhQj/IMG_1724.jpeg)\n*New roof!*\n\n![IMG_1718.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmegFRUeiy5PYvWH6tDzUC8B9L8n1VRcB8P4CZCpeZZomj/IMG_1718.jpeg)\n\n![IMG_1679.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmRDjU4ucYzUE7d8Tr5VMBNjqLRFXRnyDFGrGSp9yKRh8X/IMG_1679.jpeg)\n*The four of us*\n\nWe have planted 30 fruit trees in the orchard and gardens and we have a few peach trees to plant soon.\n\nJust cutting the lawns is a mammoth task, not to mention the main field needs regular cutting so the grass can win through the weeds. Some of the weeds are dangerous for horses – ragwort can kill, buttercups and docks are noxious and prolific.\n\n![IMG_2461.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmXtEMj4gwgfVM9dCcAiysECwukZPrPDS5zSw5pEQAwEgf/IMG_2461.jpeg)\n*This field takes more than an afternoon to cut*\n\nIn the late winter, our friend Gail mowed the tree line to collect fallen leaves for the raised beds (Gail and Tommo are married and live on a boat in Greek waters during the summer). \n\n![IMG_1739.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVkAnbQGrS8VNtsSAztpWwRYyASadFXRgc8B332MxruDF/IMG_1739.jpeg)\n*Gail having a moment with Tora and the chickens*\n\nTommo and @s0u1 made a base for the greenhouse with off-cuts from the local woodyard, saving a small fortune on buying an equivalent structure from a store.\n\n![IMG_1789.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTEyfDJ9CxBsuEGeNYrRPHp8b9kfJCCLJccfcUq4JoQKS/IMG_1789.jpeg)\n*Substantial base*\n\n![IMG_2113.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmVDz2gohJbFL52kFEP3SxsTsdRPjCqsQipc9VGanRkDTy/IMG_2113.jpeg)\n*Work in progress*\n\n![IMG_2248.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmQ4TCXCpiQn9F9hb4UwbhjQGjPY4yeR1ygshzuA46BwJs/IMG_2248.jpeg)\n*Finished!*\n\n![IMG_1796.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmUGwpuWhH22du9Z4R4kw3FRWhiiiHZzvAN5qRbQe914jZ/IMG_1796.jpeg)\n*Big sky!*\n\n\nIn the gardens we grow apples (some new trees, some old and in need of pruning), pears, cherries (also old trees, plus wild cherries in the woods), plums, peach, and some citrus trees in pots as I need to protect them from cold.\n\nWe have 7 established hazel trees, a wild plum/cherry that is beautiful in spring, and a few established ornamental trees – Japanese maple, beech, sycamore, cherry laurel, ‘Red Robin’ (photinia) etc. The majority of the woodlands is made up of oak, some pine/fir, birch, cherry, sweet chestnut. There is also the problem of Scottish broom, an invasive, non-native (if beautiful) bush that needs taking in hand as the seed pods spread across a wide area, it has no nutritional benefit for domestic or wild animals and the dried, woody plant makes wildfires easier to start.\n\nWe have grapes too. The plan is to train the vines up and over a trellis and network of wire supports, to create a living sunshade over the patio area. The field across the road was a working vineyard back in the 1950s and some vines still grow in the woods that sprung up when the vineyard failed. \n\nI have three wisteria seedlings grown from a pod I found on a visit to one of the local towns. I have high hopes for those. I also have three passion flower vines. They are currently growing up some home-made trellis and I have plans to move them soon.\n\nOne of the many delights for me is collecting seeds and planting them in my own garden. I have a few ‘free trees’ that I’ve discovered and I’m leaving them where they sprouted (at least for the moment).\n\nThe views to the front and to the back of the property are wonderful. To the front, we get the sunrise (which I don’t often witness) and the sunsets across the back are breath-taking.\n![IMG_2398.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmcX5eAzYvF8h9a3prnVgVLaNgjoswUfdgS3FkGrwxGLF4/IMG_2398.jpeg)\n*Moon at the front of the house. There's a lot of sky over there!*\n\n\n![IMG_2370.jpeg](https://images.hive.blog/DQmTujjXKGjP3HdQqpngvSb3PFdXj5Ms14DJBqNpAJ1qJLz/IMG_2370.jpeg)\n*Sunset over the valley to the back of the house*\n\nThanks for reading my roundup of gardening adventures. I hope you enjoyed the pictures too.",
